subject: RE: The goals of CMM (Re: [junit] wanted Junit professionals urgently)
msgSnippet: I realize this is no longer a JUnit topic, but I couldn t resist adding my 2 cents (and I m quite broke, ... Right, but process definitions help people take
messageBody:
I realize this is no longer a JUnit topic, but I
couldn't resist adding my 2 cents (and I'm quite broke,
so I won't be adding any more 2 cents):

> Process definitions don't write software; people do.

Right, but process definitions help people take care of
the more mundane tasks in software development. Perhaps
every heretofore uncharted business domain may provide
artistic freedom for a software developer, but pretty soon,
it becomes yet another "patternizable", "automated testable"
piece of software.
>
> From what I understand the goal of CMM is to define a
> process that even
> a monkey could follow. Monkeys do not write software; people do.

perhaps the monkey refers to "code monkeys"...
Again, my point is that a large part of software being built today
is grunt-work, which can and should be codified in a process.
>
> It drives towards more uniform results, certainly; but I don't know
> about "better software".

At the end, if you're saying the concept of the CMM is BS, I don't
agree. The very fact that we're using JUnit and other tools to
complement our laziness (laziness being a compliment, of course, in
software development) is evidence that we are trying to get from
Initial to Repeatable (this word is JUnit all the way) to Defined
to Managed to Optimized (refactor mercilessly).
if you're saying the process (documentation, documentation and more
documentation) is flawed, I'm with you.

Finally, I just took a look at http://www.sei.cmu.edu and found out
that they're sunsetting the CMM and moving to CMMI, so maybe they
did find out that most people out here cared two hoots about the
process...

regards,
Nilesh
